metadata.sermon_start_end: Giant fists and midget hearts, university graduates in things physical, kindergarten failures in things spiritual. Thus might we well describe our day and generation. There have been ages and eras in which people desired to bless the world but lacked the physical equipment. Ours is an age in which we [...] This is not something open to any secret few. This is a capacity and a power available to any person who will have it. It is a part of our spiritual birthright as the sons and daughters of God. There is a power which is available to us which we can have if we will. And if our circumstances cannot be altered, what is more important is that this internal exuberance can give you joy and peace in the midst of hard trials and heavy loads? This is available to you. Appropriate it now. It is yours!

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon uses John 4:32 as a springboard for a general discourse on spirituality versus materialism. It fails Dekker's requirement to find what is unique to THIS text. The specific context of the Samaritan woman and the messianic revelation is treated as a mere 'scene' rather than the source of a unique word.
quotes: There is a scene in the life of Jesus which strikingly sets this forth.
Jesus was waiting for the return of his disciples when he happened to meet a Samaritan woman
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Identify what the 'food' of Jesus is specifically in the context of the Father's will (v. 34), rather than generalizing it as 'invisible supplies'.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: Exegesis is minimal. There is no engagement with the Greek text or the specific theological tensions between Jews and Samaritans that inform the passage. The preacher uses the text to illustrate a pre-conceived psychological point about 'interior wealth'.
quotes: Now, this was no comment of scorn about physical needs.
There were early heresies within the church which tried to minimize our Lord's humanity
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Examine the meaning of 'food' (βρῶμα) in Johannine theology and the significance of the harvest imagery that immediately follows the chosen verse.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete regarding the 'zeitgeist' (technology, race relations, travel), which Dekker values. However, it often slips into general truths about 'spiritual calm' rather than text-specific application.
quotes: Our modern communications are instantaneous... we seem to have so little worth saying
Blacks and whites use the same words but give to them vastly different meanings.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Connect the contemporary 'restlessness' specifically to the 'thirst' and 'hunger' addressed in John 4, rather than using general psychological categories.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is structured as a long social/psychological introduction followed by a brief biblical illustration. Exposition and application are not mixed; the text is 'applied' to the preacher's theme rather than the hearer being 'expounded' by the text.
quotes: The good news of the gospel is that we can have deep, invisible interior supplies... There is a scene in the life of Jesus which strikingly sets this forth.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Start with the text and let the contemporary analysis emerge from the specific words of Jesus, rather than using the text as a late-stage illustration.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: Misery is present as 'restlessness' and 'public irresponsibility'. Redemption is framed as 'interior wealth'. However, it leans too heavily on human psychology and 'capacity' rather than the objective work of Christ.
quotes: our impoverishment of invisible spiritual supplies.
this internal exuberance can give you joy and peace
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Clarify that the 'redemption' is not a human 'capacity' or 'birthright' to be appropriated, but a gift from the 'One Lord'.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The 'two ways' are largely absent. The sermon suggests a 'birthright' available to all, lacking the gravity of being 'lost' (temporal or eternal). It functions more as an invitation to a better lifestyle than a call to a life-and-death decision.
quotes: This is a capacity and a power available to any person who will have it.
Appropriate it now. It is yours!
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Incorporate the consequence of remaining in 'materialism' or 'restlessness' as a form of being 'lost in time'.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned and His two natures are defended against docetism, which aligns with Dekker. However, Christ is more an example of 'spiritual supply' than the telos of the sermon. The focus remains on the hearer's 'adequacy'.
quotes: Jesus Christ, very man, very God, did get hungry
This is possible in your daily living. You can move in the midst of disaster... and yet, in another sense, live above it.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Shift the focus from the hearer's 'internal exuberance' to Christ as the only source of life outside of oneself.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 14 minutes (1450 words), the sermon fails Dekker's 20-minute minimum. It lacks the 'breadth' required for theological 'depth'.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical section to allow the text to speak more fully before rushing to psychological application.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker’s criteria primarily because it treats the biblical text as an illustration for a psychological/sociological thesis. It lacks the necessary length for depth and fails to provide a specific exposition of John 4:32. While it accurately diagnoses the 'zeitgeist', it offers 'internal exuberance' as a solution rather than the specific, external grace of Christ found in the Word.
strengths: Adequate diagnosis of contemporary cultural restlessness and the limits of technology.
Clear defense of the two natures of Christ (Thesis 7).
Concrete references to social issues like race and family life (Thesis 3).
weaknesses: Insufficient length (14 minutes) prevents the 'breadth' Dekker requires.
The text is used as a 'scene' to support a theme, not as a unique Word of God.
The 'two ways' are missing; the sermon lacks the urgency of the possibility of being lost.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the strict sense of Dekker's definition. It is a spiritual-psychological speech that uses a Bible passage as a motif rather than an exposition and application of a specific Word of God.
